Award.AwardTitle: SHINE: Systematic Evaluation of the Coronal and Heliospheric Models Installed at the Community Coordinated Modeling Center (CCMC)
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Principal Investigator (PI) and her collaborator will evaluate the success of several models now being hosted at the Community Coordinated Modeling Center (CCMC) at NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center, to determine how these models can best be used and how they could be improved. This effort will specifically focus on the Wang-Sheeley-Arge (WSA) coronal model, the Magnetohydrodynamics-Around-A-Sphere (MAS) coronal model, the ENLIL heliospheric/solar wind model ("Enlil" was the Sumerian wind god), and the Space Weather Modeling Framework (SWMF), in order to systemically evaluate their capabilities in simulating the solar corona and solar wind structure for the solar minimum period of 2007-09. To compare model output with multi-spacecraft observations, the PI's team will test about 246 model runs for each solar Carrington rotation and for each available spacecraft as an observation source, in order to fully assess the differences in model output caused by the varying solar boundary conditions measured by different spacecraft, as opposed to variations caused by different physics or numerical treatments in the various models. Because these team members are not involved in developing specific models, they can provide an unbiased evaluation of the advantages and disadvantages of each model and in this way, assist the original developers with model validation and enhancement.

This effort will advance the community's ability to use the models at the CCMC to accurately simulate solar wind evolution in the inner heliosphere and to connect phenomena occurring on the Sun with solar wind structures. This evaluation of the CCMC's solar corona and solar wind models is a necessary step in validating the tools needed for further advances in space physics research and in space weather forecasting. The PI is a young female postdoc who will receive mentoring and career development through this project, thereby enhancing the participation of underrepresented groups in the physical sciences. The Co-PI also will incorporate these results into his courses teaching undergraduate and graduate students. The team will disseminate these research results broadly through participation at annual scientific meetings and workshops.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we have systematically evaluated multiple coronal and heliospheric models installed at the Community Coordinated Modeling Center (CCMC) for the solar wind prediction, which is vital for the space weather forecasting. Because we are not involved in developing specific models, this project works as an unbiased broker.

Achievements in Intellectual Merit:

The models assessed include Magnetohydrodynamics-Around-a-Sphere (MAS) from Predictive Science Inc. and Wang-Sheeley-Arge (WSA) coronal models coupled with Enlil heliospheric model by Dusan Odstrcil, Space Weather Modeling Framework (SWMF) from University of Michigan, and interplanetary scintillation (IPS) tomography from University of California, San Diego. The full-Sun synoptic maps from the Global Oscillation Network Group are used for all the models, while maps from other solar observatories are used for WSA-Enlil model (the model currently used at NOAA Space Weather Prediction Center) to evaluate the effects of different magnetograms.  

First, we have run different versions of MAS-Enlil and WSA-Enlil models during ACE and Ulysses radial alignment in 2004, and compared the simulation results of stream interaction regions (SIRs) with ACE and Ulysses observations near Earth and Jupiter orbits, respectively. We have assessed the changes with model upgrades and compared two sets of magnetograms. Meanwhile, we have studied the radial evolution of solar wind and published the results in Jian et al. (Solar Physics, 2011).

Second, we have compared the results from 10 different couplings of solar magnetogram, coronal and heliospheric models in 2007 with spacecraft observation near Earth, at Ulysses, MESSENGER, Venus Express, and STEREO. The relative performance of models depends largely on evaluation criterion. Thus, we have developed comprehensive model performance metrics including the capabilities of capturing the magnetic field sector boundaries, SIRs, and latitudinal variations of solar wind. Automatic feature identification codes have been developed and applicable to other studies. We have found the models generally underestimate the magnetic field intensity and fast wind temperature, the MAS-Enlil model captures the solar wind patterns well, the WSA-Enlil model captures the normalized solar wind parameters well, while the IPS tomography captures the SIRs best. The validation results for near-Earth solar wind are published in Jian et al. (Space Weather, 2015); the paper with Ulysses comparison was submitted to Space Weather and is currently under revision. Other results are presented in conferences and seminars.

Third, we have participated in the comprehensive studies of several space weather events, and the validation of ensemble modeling of coronal mass ejections through collaboration, resulting in four coauthored publications.

In total, the work from the project has been published in three first-authored papers and four coauthored papers, presented in three seminars and 13 conferences including five invited talks. One of the papers is nominated by Solar Physics for the Springer campaign “Change the World, One Article at a Time: Must Read Articles from 2015!” intended to showcase the single most significant article per journal from 2015. The conference presentations are accessible to public online through the PI’s homepage.
